Description: Cream slipped neck-less ovoid/globular jar, with handles. Also known as a ‘meat jar’. Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Neck-less ovoid/globular jars, found with and without handles, are known as ‘meat jars’. Common from the 18th Dynasty onwards (Ruffieux 2010, fig. 23.6 & 9; Rzepka et al. 2011, 161, 166, figs 55.5-6, 59.5; Wodzińska 2012, fig. 3; Aston 1998, 478-486; Kemp 2012; Wodzińska 2010, NK8, NK28, NK27; Petrie Museum UC42253 and UC19194-5). However 19th to 20th Dynasty parallels are also knwon (Budka 2006, 101, fig. 11.3-4; Aston et al. 1998, 210, pl. 44, no. 382; 209, pl. 43, no. 373; 202, pl.36, no. 306; 202, pl. 35, no. 298; 196, fig. 30, no.251; Meyer and Heidorn 2011, 12-15, figs 6-7, nos 12-16; Aston 1999, pls 4, 7, 8, nos 72, 150, 176; pl. 8, no. 173).
